#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Finnmark
#Text=Finnmark ( Sami : Finnmárkku fylka ) is Norway 's northernmost county , well within the Arctic circle .
#Text=It is the largest county in Norway by area ( 48,637 km ) but the smallest by inhabitants ( 74,000 in 2012 ) .
#Text=Finnmark is the northernmost part of mainland Europe , as well as the easternmost part of Norway .
#Text=Towns
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=Understand
#Text=Finnmark covers an area about the size of countries like Slovakia , Switzerland or Denmark .
#Text=From west to east it is almost 1000 km , comparable to the distance from London to Edinburgh .
#Text=A large part of the county consists of the Finnmarksvidda plateau at about 300 to 500 meters above sea level .
#Text=Finnmark 's rugged coastline totals about 6800 km if islands are included ( more than the coastline of Spain or Chile ) .
#Text=The municipality of Kautokeino is about 10,000 square kilometers ( 4 times the size of Luxembourg ) with a population of less than 3,000 .
#Text=Almost 10 % of Kautokeino 's area is lake surface .
#Text=In total there are well over 100,000 lakes in Finnmark .
#Text=In Eastern Finnmark the borders of Finland , Norway and Russia coincide , with no less than three different time zones within a few steps .
#Text=Finnmark is the northernmost as well as the easternmost part of Scandinavia .
#Text=Kirkenes sits at about 30°E , corresponding to St. Petersburg or Istanbul .
#Text=Climate and daylight
#Text=Finnmark is Norway 's coldest area , but temperatures varies over the county .
#Text=The interior has a continental climate with winter temperatures down to -40°C/F ( record -50°C ) , while summers can be warm .
#Text=Karasjok for instance has an annual average at .
#Text=The coast has chilly summers , and winters that are not so cold but windy ( the open sea is ice free in winter ) .
#Text=The town of Vardø has an Arctic climate , as even July has a monthly average at 9°C , like most of the outer coastline of Finnmark .
#Text=During summer there is a long period of midnight sun ( 24 hour sun ) and vice versa
#Text=there is a long period in winter during which the sun is below the horizon ( polar night , skábma or mørketid , " dark period " ) .
#Text=In Alta the polar night lasts from November 25 to January 17 .
#Text=History
#Text=Finnmark was largely destroyed during World War II .

#Text=The eastern part of Finnmark was on the front between Soviet Union and Germany ; fierce fighting took place east of the small town of Kirkenes , which was subjected to more than 300 bombing raids .
#Text=When the occupying forces retreated to Troms , they applied a scorched earth strategy , where virtually every home , church , factory , bridge and telegraph pole was destroyed .
#Text=The population was relocated by force to Tromsø and further south .
#Text=The result was a vast no-man 's land about twice the size of Belgium ( similar tactics was applied across the border in Northern Finland ) .
#Text=Kirkenes and eastern Finnmark was liberated by the Soviet army 1944 , the Soviets retreated in 1945 .
#Text=Some 20,000 residents refused to relocate and endured the winter in tunnels , caves and makeshift lodgings .
#Text=The county was quickly rebuilt after the war , virtually no building older than 1945 exist .
#Text=Finnmark was for centuries Norway 's frontier .
#Text=The very northern regions of Norway , Sweden , Finland and Russia was largely a common area without clear boundaries until 1826 .
#Text=Along with the Sami people and Norwegians there are also Kven people of Finnish origin in Finnmark .
#Text=There have been close connections across the border to Finland and Russia .
#Text=Trade with the Pomors of Russia even resulted in a local pidgin language that mixed elements of Russian and Norwegian , as well as words from English , French , Sami and other languages .
#Text=Talk
#Text=Norwegian is spoken by all , but in parts of Finnmark Nortern Sami is the majority language and there is a Kven/ Finnish speaking minority as well .
#Text=Sami is a family of languages and the northern variant spoken in Finnmark and Troms is the most common .
#Text=Sami languages are also spoken in Finland , Russia and Sweden .
#Text=As in rest of Norway , English proficiency is good .
#Text=Signs are often with Sami names in addition to Norwegian names , for instance Kautokeino is spelled Guovdageaidnu in Sami .
#Text=In Eastern Finnmark around Kirkenes , Russian is used on signs and also spoken .
#Text=Well over 10 % of the population in Kirkenes are Russians .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Finnmark is located on the very north of the Fenno-Scandinavian landmass , just north of Finland .
#Text=Mode of transport and route is therefore important .
#Text=Overland transport is very time consuming from most places , including South Scandinavia .
#Text=For a brief visit air transport is usually the only realistic option .
#Text=Overland transport from South Scandinavia and the European mainland is fastest and easiest – but less scenic – through Sweden and Finland .
#Text=The shortest road from for instance Hamburg to North Cape is about 2800 km ( 1700 miles ) , more than 30 hours non-stop driving .
#Text=There is a single border crossing from Russia near Kirkenes ( note that this is an outer border of Schengen ) .
#Text=There is no rail network this far north ( you get to Bodø , Narvik , Luleå , Kolari , Rovaniemi or Murmansk , you can take your car on some trains or continue by bus ) .
#Text=By plane
#Text=There are direct flights from Oslo to Alta ( ALF ) and Kirkenes ( KKN ) and in summertime also to Lakselv ( LKL ) , served by SAS or Norwegian .
#Text=Other airports are Båtsfjord ( BJF ) , Berlevåg , Hammerfest , Hasvik , Honningsvåg , Lakselv , Mehamn , Vadsø , Vardø .
#Text=They are served by local flights from either Alta , Kirkenes or Tromsø ( TOS ) , operated by Widerøe .
#Text=There are ( per 2015 ) no international flights .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Eskelisen Lapin Linjat offers bus rides from Finland to Vadsø , Alta , and Nordkapp .
#Text=Regional express buses from Tromsø to Alta , about 7 hours .
#Text=By boat
#Text=Hurtigruten coastal ships , daily departures
#Text=By car
#Text=From Norway : The E6 , from South Norway
#Text=this is longer but more scenic road than E4 .
#Text=From South Norway through Sweden and Finland
#Text=E4 is fastest also from Oslo .
#Text=A suggestion is to drive E6 , 3 , 25 , 311 past Trysil and Särna , then 314 , 83 and E14 past Sveg and Ånge to Sundsvall and the E4 .
#Text=A longer but better road is E16 to Gävle .
#Text=From Sweden and through Finland
#Text=Fastest
#Text=from south Sweden to Alta : E4 to Luleå , then E10 and 392 and 403 past Pajala to the border to Finland , then E8 and road 93 .
#Text=Fastest from south Sweden to Kirkenes : E4 to Kemi ( in Finland ) , then E75 and road 971 .
#Text=Finnish highway 4 ( E75 ) stretches from Helsinki up to the " head " of Finland from where you can continue to west to Lakselv , north to Tana or east to Kirkenes .
#Text=Helsinki itself is connected by ferry from Tallinn , Travemünde and Stockholm .
#Text=European route 105 ( E105 ) enters from Russia at Storskog border crossing 15 km east of Kirkenes .
#Text=This is the only overland crossing between Norway and Russia .
#Text=Crossing by vehicle only , no pedestrians nor cyclists ( as of January 2016 ) .
#Text=Note : This is an outer border of Schengen .
